description: Number of prime divisors of n! + 1 (counted with multiplicity).
comments: The smallest k! with n prime factors occurs for n in A060250.103!+1 = 27437*31084943*C153, so a(103) is unknown until this 153-digit composite is factored. a(104) = 4 and a(105) = 6. - _Rick L. Shepherd_, Jun 10 2003
links: Hisanori Mishima, Factorizations of many number sequences
Hisanori Mishima, Factorizations of many number sequences
R. G. Wilson v, Explicit factorizations
mathematica: a[q_] := Module[{x, n}, x=FactorInteger[q!+1]; n=Length[x]; Sum[Table[x[[i]][[2]], {i, n}][[j]], {j, n}]]A054990[n_Integer] := PrimeOmega[n! + 1]; Table[A054990[n], {n,100}] (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Jul 22 2011 *)
crossrefs: Cf. A000040 (prime numbers), A001359 (twin primes). Also A054988, A054989, A054991, A054992.
Cf. A066856 (number of distinct prime divisors of n!+1), A084846 (mu(n!+1)).
